results.headline: About Those Visitors From Other Planets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sirius

results.summary_short: “Sirius,” a documentary by Amardeep Kaleka, seeks to induce government transparency about extraterrestrial life.

results.headline: Suspending Disbelief, as 4 Flee Handcuffs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Now You See Me

results.summary_short: “Now You See Me,” directed by Louis Leterrier, follows the exploits of a criminal group of magicians as they are pursued by a dogged F.B.I. agent.

results.headline: Uncle Sam Stands in the Way of Uncle Jack

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Do

results.summary_short: A British man living in New York sees his life crumble when his work visa is denied, in Glenn Gaylord’s “I Do.”

results.headline: A Father-Son Outing Goes Terribly Wrong

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After Earth

results.summary_short: “After Earth,” the Will Smith-Jaden Smith vehicle directed by M. Night Shyamalan, a boy and his dad crash-land on a planet that their ancestors ruined and fled.

results.headline: How It Looks to Think: Watch Her

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Arendt

results.summary_short: Margarethe von Trotta’s “Hannah Arendt” examines both the life and work of its subject.

results.headline: Dissertation Tests a Grad Student’s Sanity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nancy, Please

results.summary_short: In “Nancy, Please, ” a Yale Ph.D. candidate deals with academic pressure and crippling fears.

results.headline: For a Hasidic Woman, Weighing the Personal Against Larger Duties

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fill the Void

results.summary_short: “Fill the Void” is about a young ultra-Orthodox Jewish woman who is placed in an uncomfortable predicament.

results.headline: Nine Years Later, Once More

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before Midnight

results.summary_short: “Before Midnight” follows the continuing romance of characters played by Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke in the third film in a series directed by Richard Linklater.

results.headline: One Built a Pipeline for Secrets, and the Other Pumped Them Out
results.display_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story of WikiLeaks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Steal Secrets: The Story of WikiLeaks

results.summary_short: Alex Gibney’s new documentary, “We Steal Secrets: The Story of WikiLeaks,” traces the intertwined actions of Julian Assange and Pfc. Bradley Manning.

results.headline: Abruptly, She Lets Down Her Hair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The English Teacher

results.summary_short: In “The English Teacher,” Julianne Moore plays a high school teacher leading a solitary life who suddenly takes a chance on a former star pupil with artistic ambitions.

results.headline: Do They Want to Go Faster? Yes, Indeed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fast & Furious 6

results.summary_short: It’s a flipomania of cars when the boys reunite in “Fast & Furious 6,” starring Vin Diesel, Dwayne Johnson and Michelle Rodriguez.

results.headline: Tiny Folk in a Big War of Good Versus Evil

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Epic

results.summary_short: “Epic,” a 3-D adventure directed by Chris Wedge, is a hymn to nature geared to families.

results.headline: Greek Hero in an All-American Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Green Story

results.summary_short: “A Green Story,” inspired by real events, is about a Greek immigrant who succeeds because of all-American hard work and an early belief in the green movement.

results.headline: Yet Another Road Trip, and More Roadkill

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hangover Part III

results.summary_short: Four of the unlikeliest on-the verge-of-middle-age buddies ever to join forces in search of adventure come together for the final edition of the “Hangover” trilogy.

results.headline: Literary Lion and a Very Good Sport
results.display_title: Plimpton! Starring George Plimpton As Himself

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Plimpton! Starring George Plimpton As Himself

results.summary_short: “Plimpton!” is a portrait of the writer and editor George Plimpton, a literary figure eclipsed by his signature participatory journalism.

results.headline: Hotshots of Street Basketball
results.display_title: Doin' It in the Park: Pick-Up Basketball, NYC

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doin' It in the Park: Pick-Up Basketball, NYC

results.summary_short: “Doin’ It in the Park’ centers on New York’s outdoor basketball courts and the players who live on them.

results.headline: Nursing Home or Frat House?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3 Geezers!

results.summary_short: In Michelle Schumacher’s “3 Geezers!” old people are living it up in their golden years.

results.headline: Blood Despite Kinship

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aurangzeb

results.summary_short: “Aurangzeb” weaves Bollywood tropes — twins separated as babies, parent-child reunions, crosses and double-crosses — with contemporary outrage at the rules of the game.

results.headline: Hollywood Does Arabia, From A to B

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valentino's Ghost

results.summary_short: Michael Singh’s documentary “Valentino’s Ghost” looks at the intersection of Western politics in the Middle East and Hollywood’s depiction of Arabs.

results.headline: In a Vicious Sadist, the Faintest Glimmer of Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pieta

results.summary_short: “Pieta,” a brutal drama by the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk, centers on a violent loan shark approached by a woman claiming to be his mother.
